posts.headline: India's Startup Scene: One Million Dreams or Delusions by 2035?
posts.description: Nandan Nilekani predicts India will host one million startups by 2035, envisioning a surge in entrepreneurial ventures.
posts.p1: Because what better way to tackle unemployment than having everyone start their own company?
posts.p2: Who needs job security when you can have the thrill of a 90% failure rate?
posts.p3: The future: a nation where everyone is a CEO, and no one has employees.
posts.p4: At this rate, the only stable job left will be 'motivational speaker.'

posts.headline: AI Tackles Schizophrenia: Machines Now Understand Us Better Than We Do
posts.description: AI and 3D printing are being utilized to aid in the treatment of schizophrenia, offering new avenues for patient care.
posts.p1: Finally, machines can empathize with the voices in our heads.
posts.p2: Next step: AI diagnosing itself with imposter syndrome.
posts.p3: Because nothing says progress like robots treating human existential crises.
posts.p4: Soon, therapy sessions will involve patients comforting their AI therapists.

posts.headline: Narayana Murthy: Freebies Won't Cure Poverty, But Your Startup Might
posts.description: Infosys co-founder Narayana Murthy emphasizes that job creation by innovative entrepreneurs, not freebies, will help eliminate poverty.
posts.p1: Because who needs social safety nets when you have visionary billionaires?
posts.p2: Poverty: best addressed by bootstraps, provided you can afford boots.
posts.p3: The rich get richer, but it's for the poor's own good.
posts.p4: Remember, if you're still poor, you just haven't innovated hard enough.
